utterance.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterance.content: Welcome to A Night of Dance, America’s favorite dance competition. With your host, Brad Melville!

utterance.speaker: BRAD MELVILLE
utterance.content: Hey, hey, hey! Good evening America! It’s dance off time and tonight’s theme is latin. As always, tonight’s challengers were handpicked by the judges. Max, are you looking forward to watching these two rumba?

utterance.speaker: MAX
utterance.content: I’m looking forward to Santino redeeming himself for his samba inspired solo dance last week. Pathetic.

utterance.speaker: PIERRE DUBOIS
utterance.content: It was like a terrible dream my dog would have after eating the leftovers of my Brazilian dinner.

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: Well then. You know our semifinalists. Our matchup is Santino versus Odette. Can the arrogant bad boy best America’s sweetheart? Let’s get right to it. Tonight’s elimination dance between Santino and Odette will mean the end of the road for one of them. One will be eliminated on Monday’s results show. The other will be garunteed a spot in the final 2. Ladies and gentlemen, Santino and Odette!

utterance.speaker: ASSISTANT
utterance.content: Odette, are you in there?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA RODGERS
utterance.content: Guess who I ran into at the beauty parlor today?

utterance.speaker: RICHARD CASTLE
utterance.content: Mother, I’m at a critical juncture and –

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oona Marconi.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oona Marconi the theater critic?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: I thought I might invite her to dinner, ask her to give a little mention to my acting school, put it into one of her columns. It would be invaluable publicity.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes well, that would depend on the mention. You aren’t forgetting her blistering review of your performance of Maggie in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, are you?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: That was 1983. I think I’m over it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: “Martha Rodgers, as Maggie the Cat, is more of a helpless kitten, mewing and flapping her hands when she doesn’t get her way.”

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: You memorized it?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I couldn’t help it! You walked around the apartment quoting it for months! Mother, I’m just saying. Maybe it’s not a good idea to ask an important favor of someone who’s been … so unkind to you in the past.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: The operative word here is ‘past’. I think I can rise above. Besides, my acting school is more important to me than some old grudge.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, that’s very mature of you, Mother.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: “If Tennessee Williams knew what kind of crimes Martha Rodgers had committed against the audience in his name, he would have her arrested for assault.”

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Rising above.

utterance.speaker: KATE BECKETT
utterance.content: C’mon, Castle. How mean can this critic be?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I’m just afraid that she’s going to get her heart broken, you know? I mean, you know my mother. On the exterior she’s a tough cookie, but … underneath all that bravado, gooey center.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hey Lanie. So who’s our victim?

utterance.speaker: LANIE PARISH
utterance.content: Odette Morton. Cause of death is a single GSW to the heart. Probably a 9 milimeter. She died instantly.

utterance.speaker: RICHARD CASTLE
utterance.content: That bullet went right through her.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, unless our killer used a silencer, someone must have heard the shot.

utterance.speaker: JAVIER ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Not necessarily. According to the stage manager, this area clears out once taping starts. Plus the opening pyrotechnics could have covered a gunshot.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, that’s assuming she was shot just as the show started.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: It looks like she was.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yeah, the makeup girl finished with Odette at 2:45, taping starts at 3, and she was discovered at 3:04.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: 19 minutes. That’s not a very big window.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: All right, see if the crew saw anyone near this room at that time.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: You got it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hey Ryan? Can I get a list of the guests that were invited to tonight’s taping along with anyone that checked in at security?

utterance.speaker: KEVIN RYAN
utterance.content: Already on it. But that’s not the only way in here. There’s an exit door to the alley down the hall. The crew guys like to prop it open so they can go out for a smoke.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So either our killer got lucky and found an unlocked door –

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Or this was an inside job.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: That gets my vote. Odette was a lock to win this thing. I bet it was one of her backstabbing rivals that did this.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: What? I watch the show. Odette was my favorite contestant. She was an heiress raised by her rich grandpa, a party girl headed down the wrong path, then a brush with death made her wake up and change her bad girl ways.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That’s a great story.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: Except for the ending.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I gotta say Dr. Parish, I never figured you for a fan of A Night of Dance.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: I’m not … exactly. It’s just … when I was young, more than anything I wanted to be a prima ballerina. If I wasn’t dancing I was thinking about dancing.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So what happened?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: The girls came around when I was 13. Not that many top heavy ballerinas out there.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, I think there should be.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Of course you do.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That’s not what I meant.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Although …

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Does Odette have any next of kin?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: Um… Paul Morton. Her brother.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, great. Bring him down here. And talk to the rest of the contestants. I want to see if anyone was taking this competition just a little too seriously.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: We understand that you and Odette were rehearsing your dance most of the day? How did she seem?

utterance.speaker: SANTINO
utterance.content: On edge. We both were. I mean, one of us was about to be eliminated, which is why I can’t believe she just left rehearsal at 11 and took off for a half an hour.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: To do what?

utterance.speaker: SANTINO
utterance.content: She wouldn’t say. But everything was riding on this dance.

utterance.speaker: JEANINE
utterance.content: She told me she had to meet a friend. She told me to cover if anyone was looking for her.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Um… do you have any idea why she was being so secretive?

utterance.speaker: JEANINE
utterance.content: The producers don’t like us to leave the stupid on show day, so if must have been important.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Well, the NYPD thanks you for your cooperation.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: You too.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Damn. Did you see that?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Mmhmm.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: She acted like I didn’t even exist.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: You don’t. Not since you put that ring on your finger. Get used to being invisible to single women.

utterance.speaker: PAUL MORTON
utterance.content: I’ve never seen her happier than these past couple months. I can’t believe that my sister’s dead.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: We understand that she had some … difficulties in the past.

utterance.speaker: PAUL
utterance.content: A few years ago our grandfather passed away and Odette took it hard. She quit school, she broke off her relationship with a nice guy, started hanging out with a bad crowd.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What kind of bad crowd?

utterance.speaker: PAUL
utterance.content: Partiers … druggies. She was arrested several times, but after the accident she left all of that behind.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That was her brush with death?

utterance.speaker: PAUL
utterance.content: It was a train derailment last year. Odette was on board. She made it out alive, but it scared the hell out of her. She turned her life around. Six months of dance training and the next thing that I know she’s auditioned for A Night of Dance and been accepted. She finally found a direction in life. She was so close to realizing her dream.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Was there anyone in Odette’s old life that could have come back to cause trouble for her?

utterance.speaker: PAUL
utterance.content: Not that I’m aware of.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What about on the show? Anyone she didn’t get along with?

utterance.speaker: PAUL
utterance.content: Uh … she did mention someone. Another contestant. I think she said his name was Eddie.

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: Detective Beckett, they’re waiting for you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: MAX
utterance.content: Detective Beckett. As co-creator and executive producer of A Night of Dance I’ve instructed my staff to provide you with anything and everything you need to help solve this terrible murder.

utterance.speaker: PAM FRANCIS
utterance.content: Anything.

utterance.speaker: PIERRE
utterance.content: Absolutely anything.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Thanks. Now, Odette told her brother that there was someone on the show that she didn’t get along with.

utterance.speaker: MAX
utterance.content: Eddie Gordon. But he’s not here anymore. Last week Eddie and Odette performed a Bob Fosse inspired number for the elimination dance off. We voted and sent Eddie home. He was upset.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: How upset?

utterance.speaker: MAX
utterance.content: Well you have to understand. All the contestants are cast on this show to tell their unique, yet familiar stories. Odette was the poor little rich girl and Eddie was the kid from the wrong side of the tracks.

utterance.speaker: MAX
utterance.content: We cast Eddie to bring the drama. Eddie brought the drama, and not just for the cameras. He was furious when we sent him packing and we all got an earful about it.

utterance.speaker: PAM
utterance.content: Oh, he was so rude.

utterance.speaker: PIERRE
utterance.content: I had to call security.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Was he threatening?

utterance.speaker: MAX
utterance.content: Let’s just say that I was relieved when we was gone. Ironic really.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: How so?

utterance.speaker: MAX
utterance.content: Well, according to the rules, when a contestant is unable to continue the last eliminated dancer returns to take his or her place.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And that dancer is Eddie Gordon.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: Let me tell you something about Miss sweet and innocent Odette. She threw me under the bus tonight. She blew off rehearsals all week, then messed up her footwork, and blames it on me. Well where I’m from we know what to do with lying b*itches like that.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: That was Eddie’s exit interview. Contestants are encouraged by producers to speak freely.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: He certainly took their advice.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Eddie’s got a record back home in Rochester. And one of the assistants at A Night of Dance says they remember seeing him in the studio the afternoon Odette was murdered.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, so Eddie was eliminated but he knew that if Odette was out of the running he’d be asked to return and take her slot.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So he went back and eliminated Odette. Permanently.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: B and E, robbery … you’re pretty busy up in Rochester, Eddie.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE GORDON
utterance.content: Yeah, but that was a long time ago. When I started dancing I gave up thug life.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, well that didn’t stop you from going off on the judges when you were eliminated.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: Me going home was the wrong call. And I said so. Maybe I said it loud, but that don’t make me no killer.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Now that Odette can’t finish the competition, the last eliminated contestant would be asked to return. And that’s you, Eddie.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: Like my Daddy used to say, the universe works in mysterious ways.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And maybe you decided to give the universe just a little shove.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So what were you doing at the studio on show day?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: I went by early to see my boy Santino. Give him support on his big day.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You’ve got an answer for everything, don’t you Eddie? You know what else you’ve got? You’ve got motive and opportunity.

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: Man, I was across town when that mess happened! Meeting my agent. But last week something was going on with Odette. Something that didn’t have nothing to do with dancing.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: She was out of it. Missing easy steps. She said she was going to the ladies room then be gone for a half an hour.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What do you think she was doing?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: I know what she was doing. I saw her go out the back door. Meet some guy in the alley. Talk real serious for a minute. Then she’d hand him a roll of bills. Looked like 3 grand, easy.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You get a good enough look at this guy? You think you can provide us with a sketch?

utterance.speaker: EDDIE
utterance.content: Yeah, I can do that.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Hey. So Eddie Gordon spoke the truth. He was meeting with his agent when Odette was shot.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So maybe he was also telling the truth about the guy he saw Odette with in the alley.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Well, he gave us a sketch. Pretty generic, though. Handosme, Caucasian, dark hair.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You know, that missing half hour when Odette left rehearsal the day she was shot, maybe she was with him.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Hmm. I’ll have uniforms circulate the sketch through the studio. See if anybody recognizes him.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Okay, so if Odette had straightened up after the train accident, what was she doing behind the stage door secretly giving some guy a roll of bills?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Could be a drug deal. Maybe Odette was falling back in to old habits. Any recent withdrawals in her bank statement?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, not for that amount of money. But check out these credit card payments. For the last 6 months Odette’s credit card spending was pretty much steady and then about a month ago it suddenly shot up.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No kidding. The cards were maxed out. Over a hundred grand in charges? What was she spending all that money on?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Thank you for coming in, Mr. Lynchberg. You were Odette’s business manager as well as the executor of her grandfather’s estate?

utterance.speaker: SAMUEL LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: And now I have the unfortunate task of handling Odette’s estate as well.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And who inherits her share of the family trust?

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: Per Odette’s wishes it goes to the Graham Morton Foundation. It’s a charitable organization.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You know, I noticed a pretty big spike in her spending over the last month. Do you have an idea what that was about?

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: I’m sure you know that after Odette’s grandfather passed away three years ago she … went through a bad period.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, her brother filled us in. Parties, drugs.

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: Of particular concern to me during that time was her spending. Odette would get drunk and … spontaneously buy a car. Or put a bid down on a new apartment. She paid for her friend’s nose job. Just, whatever struck her fancy. But then after the train accident last year, all that stopped. It was refreshing to those of us who cared about her. I was worried that last month’s credit card charges indicated that she might have been backsliding.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What was she buying?

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: Clothing, mostly. The bulk of the charges were over two days at one particular 5th Avenue department store.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I’d like to see the original receipts.

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: This is the weirdest spending spree I have ever seen. Odette spent tens of thousands of dollars on clothes, but nothing in her size, according to these receipts. Everything’s a size 4.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: I went through her apartment. I didn’t see a hundred grand worth of new clothes. Maybe she hid ‘em.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Sounds to me like the old gas card scam.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, your parents put you on a strict allowance, but they give you a gas card so you can fill your car. Well, you fill your friend’s cars and they give you cash. Some of my buddies in boarding school nearly doubled their allowance.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Uh huh.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Not me, of course. That – Don’t tell my mother.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: So Odette needed cash in a hurry, to say maybe … pay off some guy in an alley?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: But the monthly stipend from her family trust wasn’t enough to cover it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So she charges the clothes, sells them to her friends. Instant cash flow.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Which is still not enough. The cards max out, the money train stops, and she can’t make payment to whoever she owes. She ends up dead.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, but do you guys think that Odette had one size 4 friend willing to pay a hundred grand for a bunch of Peg jeans and a faux rabbit purse?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Did you say rabbit?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Jasmine? We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Where’d you get the bag?

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: A friend gave it to me.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Your friend Odette Morton? We talked to the salesperson, Jasmine. She said that you were with Odette when she dropped a hundred grand on clothes for you.

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: Odette was very generous.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: She’s also very dead and I know a blackmail scheme when I hear one.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe Odette had something going on in her personal life she wanted to keep secret. You found out about it but told her the price for your silence was a closet full of fancy duds.

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: But why would I kill her?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe she couldn’t give any more. You got frustrated, you killed her. Maybe she decided to come forward herself, accuse you of blackmail. You killed her. Jasmine, these are just off the top of my head.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We can finish off this conversation in the precinct.

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: Wait. Last month I was here working late. And I happened to see Odette walk by my desk real fast, like she was upset. Next thing I know here comes Brad Melville like he’s looking for her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Brad Melville, the show’s host? Why would the host of A Night of Dance be looking for a contestant. Aren’t they not supposed to fraternize?

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: That’s why I followed him. Brad and Odette were in the stairwell having a fight.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: About what?

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: I’m not completely sure. But when I bluffed Odette that I was going to tell Max about her and Brad she got really nervous. She offered to buy me some stuff I wanted if I’d keep quiet. And I thought that sounded like a good deal. But that’s it. I would have never hurt Odette.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You’ll have to pardon me if I don’t take you at your word.

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: Look, if anyone had a reason to murder Odette it was Brad. Just listen. I recorded the two of them.

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: We had a deal.

utterance.speaker: ODETTE
utterance.content: And I’m willing to stand by it if you are.

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: I have worked too hard to get where I am. If anyone finds out about this, Odette, I swear I’ll kill you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: If Max Renfro found out that Brad Melville was in a relationship with one of the contestants, what would happen?

utterance.speaker: JASMINE
utterance.content: She’d be thrown off the show and he’d be fired.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Motive for murder, anyone?

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: If anyone finds out about this, Odette, I swear I’ll kill you.

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: That is completely not what it sounds like.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What it sounds like, Brad, is you threatening Odette Morton’s life a few weeks before she was murdered.

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: But I was trying to protect her!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Protect her how?

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: I knew about Odette’s troubled past. The drugs, the DUIs. But I also believed her when she said that she was clean now and that dancing was all she cared about.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are you trying to say that that wasn’t true?

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: What I’m trying to say is two months ago I walked into makeup early and found Odette shooting up.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are you sure about this?

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: 100% positive. If Max knew she was using she would have been eliminated on the spot.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: But you never told Max.

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: Odette promised she would clean up. I gave her a second chance. But I also kept an eye on her. Then a month ago I caught her again. I told her I was going to Max, that she was on her own.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And did you?

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: No. Because Odette threatened me. She said that if I went to Max and told him what I’d seen, that she’d go to him and tell him that I was the one that let her off the first time. Max would have fired me for keeping a secret that big from him. I’d be off the show! I’d be Brian Dunkleman!

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Who’s Brian Dunkleman?

utterance.speaker: BRAD
utterance.content: Exactly.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So if Odette went down she was taking you with her.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Brad was right about her shooting up. Found these hidden under a false bottom in her jewelry box. No wonder CSU missed it when they went through her apartment.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Could be speed.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, except I just got off the phone with Lanie. She said that preliminary tox screen results show that Odette wasn’t using drugs. A least, none of the usual ones. So what the hell is in this bottle?

utterance.speaker: OONA MARCONI
utterance.content: And so, I said to Sir Lawrence, “Larry, that is the second best performance of Othello that I have ever seen. But I’m afraid no one can improve the Orson Welles interpretation. Larry,” I said, “you simply have been outdone.”

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oh!

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS CASTLE
utterance.content: What did Olivier say to that?

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: He said, “My dear girl, you have the makings of a theater critic.”

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: So here I am.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Yes indeed you are. Oh, by the way. I don’t know if I told you that recently I opened my own acting school.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Martha! How wonderful!

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: How good of you to share your years and … years of experience with a new generation.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes, we are very proud.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: And I was wondering. Perhaps you might consider stopping by and sitting in on a class or two and then, if you felt so inclined, mentioning our little school in one of your columns.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: I’d be happy to do that. You just tell me when and where.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Well, that’s lovely.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: I just hope you’re not teaching your students your little trick of tilting your head before delivering an important line of dialogue.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: I don’t do that.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Well, you did it when you played Maggie the Cat.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Oh, and you fluttered your hands like little bird wings. I kept waiting for you to take off.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Who wants pie? Alexis, would you? Thank you.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: I believe that was the year that I was nominated for a Tony.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Well, perhaps the American theater wing is more tolerant of head tilting and hand fluttering than I am.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Oh Martha, I’m just teasing. You can’t possibly still be upset about that old review.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Let’s not say anything that we’ll regret.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: That was no review. That was a hatchet job. It was vicious and it was uncalled for.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: And it was also accurate.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Rise above. Rise above.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: You know what, Oona? I rescind my request. There is no way that I would accept your endorsement of my school now if you begged me.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Fat chance of that! Just remember, Martha. Those who can’t do, teach.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: And those who can’t teach become theater critics!

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Gram…

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Could have been worse.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It couldn’t have been worse. My mother exposed her gooey center and Oona Marconi drove a stake through it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well, tell her I feel her pain.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Thanks. I will. Anything new on the case?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, unis found the café that Odette went to the day that she was killed.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Scoring drugs off her mystery man?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: More like scoring a fat free latte. She met up with a friend for a coffee. Suzanne Steiner.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: A friend. Leaving the studio on show day was a very big deal. What was so important that it couldn’t wait?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: According to Suzanne, she just wanted to talk about old times.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Hey. We got a fax from the lab. That clear vial of liquid that we found at Odette’s apartment? It wasn’t illegal drugs. It’s insulin.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Odette was diabetic?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Not according to her doctor. He says he hasn’t seen her in over a year.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well maybe she developed it recently. Or maybe she went to a new doctor.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Then why not just tell Brad Melville the truth? That it wasn’t speed. It was insulin. And why bother buying Jasmine half of 5th Avenue to keep it quiet?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Well, I think I can help with that. CSU report is back in Odette’s place. They only found one set of prints and they were not Odette’s. They belong to a woman named Barbra Landau.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Who the hell is Barbra Landau?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Not someone who would run in Odette’s circles. She was raised in foster care and was a high school dropout.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So she was staying with Odette?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We need to talk to her.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: That’s gonna be tough. Officially Barbra Landau’s been dead for over a year. Here’s her death certificate.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: She died of blunt force trauma from injuries suffered in a train collision.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: That’s right. The same train collision that Odette survived. Or did she? You see that picture of Odette? Well, this is Barbra.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: They’re identical.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: But that’s impossible.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Impossible? Or the explanation to everything? The dramatic change in Odette after the accident. The need to hide being a diabetic, because Odette was not a diabetic.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Odette Morton didn’t survive that train crash. Barbra did.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And like a phoenix rising from the ashes Barbra Landau walked away from the wreckage of that train and stole Odette Morton’s life.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Twin girls are born and put up for adoption. Odette goes to a wealthy, loving family. Barbra, not so lucky. She gets bounced around from one foster home to the next, always knowing deep inside that she was meant for something better. Then, one day, the two of them meet on a train bound for Miami. The connection is instantaneous. In two days, they learn everything there is to know about each other and Barbra can’t help but think, if only I had landed in the lap of luxury like Odette, I could have been anything I wanted to be.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are you suggesting that Barbra purposefully caused the derailment to take over Odette’s life? With what, her crazy Wiccan powers?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh. Wow, that would be an incredible twist.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But no. No. The accident happens. Odette is killed. Barbra survives. And in the midst of all the chaos and rubble, she sees her chance. She switches identification with Odette and she changes her destiny. In one move Barbra builds herself a better future. A perfect life.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Until she was murdered a year later.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah well, separated twin stories never end happily. Except The Parent Trap.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Blood tests are back. Odette and Barbra were not biologically related.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Barbra has no living family that we could find.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well if they’re not related how can Barbra look so much like Odette?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: I don’t know. But we do have an address for her former place of employment. A strip club in Midtown.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: See we’ve been operating under the theory that Odette was killed because she was Odette. But what if she was murdered because she was really Barbra?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Find out everything you can about Barbra. In the meantime, I’m going to reinterview Odette’s brother, Paul.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Is he a person of interest now?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I’m just having trouble believing that Barbra managed to fool Odette’s own brother for over a year. He’s going to have to convince me that he didn’t know.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well that sounds like something better done one on one, mano-a-mano. I’m going to take a ride downtown with the boys, check out that strip club –

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Sorry, Castle. Three’s a crowd.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: What’s up? Why’re you freezing out our boy like that?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I want to try an experiment. Having Castle along would mess things up.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Here. Wear my wedding ring.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: What? Get that thing away from me, man. It’s a mood killer.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Just wear it when we’re at the club.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: What for?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: See, I’ve been talking to all my married guy friends. They say that your theory is way off. Wearing a wedding ring gets them more attention from women, not less.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: So…

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: So, wear the ring.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I want to see if women still flirt with you and ignore me.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: So you didn’t want Castle to come because –

utterance.speaker: RYAN_ESPOSITO
utterance.content: All the women would flirt with him.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I want to know if it’s just the ring that’s repelling members of the fairer sex.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: It’s not the ring, bro. It’s you.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: See, once you’ve been married for a little while and you’re feeling a little bored and unsatisfied the ring will get you love from the ladies. They’ll want to take you away from all that so you can be bored and unsatisfied with them.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Why not now?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Because now you’re all blissfully happy with your wife and whatnot. You have the stink of honeymoon phase all over you. No woman wants to be around that.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: How long does it last?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: It’s hard to say. But knowing you and Jenny, probably forever.

utterance.speaker: CHANTAL
utterance.content: Oh yeah, Barbie. All she wanted to do was be a dancer on Broadway.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: She used to talk about it a lot, huh?

utterance.speaker: CHANTAL
utterance.content: More than that. She got a makeover, changed her hair. And then two years ago she got her nose done, even though her nose looked fine before.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Back in the day did Barbra have trouble with anybody? Say a customer? Maybe a boyfriend?

utterance.speaker: CHANTAL
utterance.content: Boyfriend, yeah. Jason.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Can this be him?

utterance.speaker: CHANTAL
utterance.content: That’s him. Jason Bagwell.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Do you know where we can find Jason?

utterance.speaker: CHANTAL
utterance.content: He lived over in Alphabet City. He was always running some scam. Borrowing money from Barbra for some business venture, never paying her back. But she loved him. Crazy love, you know?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Oh yeah. I do.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Well, you’ve been very helpful, Chantal. Thank you for your time.

utterance.speaker: CHANTAL
utterance.content: If you wanted, you could come back later. My show starts at 8.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: I could probably get –

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: He’s gotta get home to the little woman, Chantal, but we do thank you for your time and your cooperation.

utterance.speaker: CHANTAL
utterance.content: All right.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: What’s wrong with you, man? Why’d you have to assault my game like that?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: You can’t pick up on honeys while wearing the eternal symbol of my love and commitment to Jenny. Did I just say that out loud?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Mmm.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: No wonder women won’t flirt with me. I’m a lost cause. A man in love with his wife.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Enjoy it, my friend. A lot of men would switch places with you. Not me. Uh uh. Other men. Guys. Unhappy single guys.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Yeah yeah yeah. Just give me my ring back and you can go get Chantal’s phone number.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: What the – Ow.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: It’s stuck.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The guys are out picking up Barbra’s ex-boyfriend, I thought I’d use the time to follow up on what they learned at the club. Starting with the fact that Barbra Landau did get plastic surgery. Here is her old DMV photo.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: She’s a pretty girl.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Exactly. Plastic surgery didn’t make her look more beautiful, it just made her look more like Odette Morton. You remember her accountant? Samuel Lynchberg told you that Odette paid for her friend’s nose job.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And you think Barbra’s that friend? You think they knew each other?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I know it. Lynchberg’s assistant confirmed it. Odette paid for Barbra’s surgery, plus expenses.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And I’m guessing you have a theory as to why?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You know Odette loved to party. Speaking from personal experience I can tell you that all that constant carousing does not come without consequences, like arrests, community service hours, waking up in a strange hotel room with some girl’s panties on your head… … that’s … forget that part. Here is Odette doing community service hours for her second DUI in 2010. Here’s Odette at a bridal shower with friends.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So according to the time stamps, these photos were taken on the same day within 20 minutes of each other.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So it was really Barbra at the soup kitchen.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Odette would do the time, but she didn’t want to do the time. So she created a Faux-dette to do her dirty work for her. A job that I bet paid very well. Maybe a wild night on the town brings Odette to the strip club where she sees Barbra. All of Barbra. And she realizes that with a little work, Barbra could be the perfect double for her, doing all the dirty jobs that Odette simply couldn’t be bothered to do. Community service hours, drug tests …

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And with a little training and some surgical tweaks, Barbra could do even more. Like meetings with Odette’s business manager or … boring luncheons with her Aunt Margaret.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Nobody in Odette’s inner circle could have known about the ruse, so that when the train crashed, Barbra saw her chance to go from understudy to leading lady and she took it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, so that explains the transition, but we still don’t know who killed her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe we do. It would have to be someone that knew that Odette was actually Barbra when he saw her on TV. Someone who was looking to cash in on her new life.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Someone like Barbra’s boyfriend Jason.

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: I’m telling you, this is crazy. I didn’t kill anybody.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Here’s what I think happened. You realized that Barbra didn’t die in that train accident. She was alive.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And living as Odette Morton, which meant that she was very rich.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You knew her secret and you wanted to be rich, too.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But Barbra wasn’t the kind of girl to claw her way into the good life and then be taken advantage of by the likes of you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: She rejected you. And so you shot her.

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: See, this is why I didn’t come forward. I knew you’d suspect me.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We suspect people with motive, Jason.

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: You’ve got it wrong. Barbra came to me. Two weeks ago she showed up on my doorstep and told me the whole story.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Barbra had everything she could want. A perfect life. Why would she risk it all by getting in touch with you?

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: Because she missed me.

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: And Odette’s life wasn’t as perfect as Barbra thought. Barbra was lonely and she wanted to get back together. She told me that she had found out some stuff about Odette… um… secrets from her past.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What kind of secrets?

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: I don’t know. But she said if anyone found out it would all be over for her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You think this secret got her killed?

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: She said she could use it to her advantage. She just needed more information. Information was leverage. It would protect her. But she had to move fast.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And she didn’t move fast enough.

utterance.speaker: JASON
utterance.content: Barbra had been dancing since she was a little kid and all she ever wanted was to be a star on Broadway. And she was so close.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So it wasn’t something from her own past that got Barbra killed. It was something from Odette’s.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, so a week before her death, Barbra as Odette is acting odd, she’s missing rehearsals –

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: She seeks out her ex, tells him that Odette’s perfect life isn’t so perfect and that there’s something in Odette’s past that’s a problem.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Right. So she needs information. So where does she go?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Suzanne Steiner. Remember Barbra met her for coffee the day she died. She wanted to talk to Suzanne about old times.

utterance.speaker: SUZANNE STEINER
utterance.content: I’m not sure what help I can be. Odette seemed fine the day that I saw her.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mmhmm.

utterance.speaker: SUZANNE
utterance.content: Oh, I keep forgetting that she wasn’t Odette. The resemblance was remarkable.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You said that she wanted to reminisce. How close were the two of you?

utterance.speaker: SUZANNE
utterance.content: My dad was the butler in her grandfather’s home for 20 years, so we practically grew up together.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And what did she want to talk about?

utterance.speaker: SUZANNE
utterance.content: Well she asked about her grandfather. Well, Odette’s grandfather.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mmhmm.

utterance.speaker: SUZANNE
utterance.content: She talked about how close they had been. And then she asked about the day that he died.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He died in his sleep, didn’t he?

utterance.speaker: SUZANNE
utterance.content: Yeah. Yeah, he was 98. It was odd that she asked, because I wasn’t there. But she was. Odette was. Along with my father and … when I reminded her of that, she asked about my dad. She said she wanted to catch up with him.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Do you know if they two of them ever spoke?

utterance.speaker: SUZANNE
utterance.content: Well I gave her his number, but I’m not sure what happened.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hmm.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: It’s not coming off. It’s like it’s soldered itself to my hand.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe it’s possessed. You know, like some sort of cursed object in a Stephen King story.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: How can I tell my wife that I’m not wearing my wedding ring because I lent it to Esposito as an experiment to see if strippers would flirt with me? Maybe she’ll see the humor in it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Not a chance.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: You’re a dead man.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So, Charles Carson, former butler to Odette’s late grandfather. No record, but get this. His name rang a bell so I looked up the guest list from Wednesdays taping and he’s on it. Odette called in a last minute ticket request for Mr. Carson.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So he was at the show?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yes. Security has him going through at 2:15, but after that no one remembers seeing him.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Okay, so Suzanne said that Faux-dette wanted to talk about the day her grandfather died. What if this was the secret that Barbra was on to? What if Graham Morton didn’t die of natural causes and she felt somehow that Charles Carson here had something to do with it?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We need to see Graham Morton’s autopsy report.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Based on my reading of the coroner’s report, I can see why Graham Morton’s death was ruled natural causes. However –

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Ooh… there’s a however.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: A very big however. Tell ‘em.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: There were some anomalies that I found suspicious. Evidence of petechiae in both eyes, fresh bruising on the right side of Mr. Morton’s nose, which could have happened if say … someone was holding a pillow over his face. All in all, I think there’s ample evidence that Mr. Morton was murdered.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Ample?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Murdered. I am just so proud –

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Dad? Work. Boundaries.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: One more thing. When I requested the file be sent over, the clerk told me that I was the second person this week to ask for it. Odette Morton was there on Tuesday.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So Barbra realized Odette’s grandfather was murdered and must have thought Carson the butler had something to do with it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And then when Carson figured out that Barbra knew too much he killed her. We’re gonna bring him in first thing in the morning.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And arrest him for a double murder.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Good morning.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Speak for yourself. Oh Richard, I really messed up. I just let my ego get the better of me. Now Oona Marconi is never going to endorse my school. She’ll probably write something negative just out of spite.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, there is a chance that you can still turn this around, but … are you willing to apologize to someone who doesn’t really deserve it?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Darling, I don’t think a simple apology is going to get me out of this.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Then in the wise words of Don Vito Corleone, you need to make her an offer she can’t refuse. And if there’s anything … and if there’s anything I can do to help, you let me know.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: I will. I will.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mr. Carson, you worked for Graham Morton for over 25 years. I understand that you were very close with his grandkids.

utterance.speaker: CHARLES CARSON
utterance.content: Well, as close as one could be while still maintaining the employer servant relationship.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So when the victim called you and invited you to the A Night of Dance taping on Wednesday, you said yes.

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: I was delighted. She asked me to meet her afterwards, said she had a question for me, but of course as you know, they cancelled the show and I didn’t find out until the next day what had happened. I had no idea that that girl wasn’t Odette. And no idea why she wanted to talk to me.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: She wanted to talk to you about the day that Graham Morton died.

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: Why would she care about that?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It seems she had some evidence that Mr. Morton didn’t die of natural causes.

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: I don’t understand. Are you saying that he was murdered?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You were at the house that day, weren’t you?

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: Oh good lord. You don’t think that I had anything –

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You were the person closest to him. You had ample opportunity.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: We’ve seen the will. He left you an ample bequest.

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: I would never have hurt Mr. Morton. But that woman – the woman who pretended to be Odette – she might be right about his death. In fact, it’s possible that she believed that I knew something. Tell me, how did Mr. Morton die? Was he smothered?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Why would you ask that?

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: The month he died there was tension in the household. Odette was seeing someone, of whom Mr. Morton did not approve.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Do you know who?

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: No, but he ordered her to break it off. And of course that day Odette was crying, she spent most of the morning in her room. And about 1 o’clock Mr. Morton said that he wanted to take a nap. So I cleared the bed of all the pillows. He preferred a flat surface. Now a few moments later there was a commotion down in the kitchen. Odette had put a sandwich in the toaster oven too long and it had caused a small fire. We put it out and then I went back upstairs to check on Mr. Morton and he was dead. And that’s when I noticed it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Noticed what?

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: A pillow. On the bed. And I was sure that I had taken them all off. So I told Odette about it, but she said my mind was playing tricks on me. So I let it go.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mr. Carson, when you were in the kitchen was there ever a moment that Odette was out of your sight?

utterance.speaker: CHARLES
utterance.content: No. I knew she was innocent.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: She wasn’t innocent. She was a distraction. Odette got you down to the kitchen while her accomplice went and murdered her grandfather.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And then when Barbra Landau figured out the truth the accomplice murdered her, too.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Thank you again for coming, Mr. Lynchberg.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Mr. Lynchberg, being the Morton family financial adviser, that must give you pretty good insight into their personal lives, right?

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: Well, looking at what people spend their money on … you get to know folks pretty well.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And how well did you know Odette?

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: As well as any of my clients. Given the lectures I’d given her about her lifestyle maybe more so.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: We understand about the time her grandfather died Odette was dating someone. Someone her grandfather didn’t approve of.

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: Oh well… that’s not surprising. The two of them rarely saw eye to eye.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: This boyfriend, do you remember who he was?

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: No. Why?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well because we think he conspired with Odette to kill her grandfather and that he killed Barbra when she was on the verge of figuring it all out.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You’re sure you don’t remember?

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well we just spoke with Odette’s brother and he remembers. In fact, he remembers it being you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: He said that they two of you wanted to get married but Odette’s grandfather threatened to cut her off.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Now, a girl like Odette, she could never be happy living off a meager six figure salary like yours. She needed to inherit. But that old man refused to die.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So she convinced you to go upstairs and smother him to death with a pillow while she created a distraction in the kitchen. Problem solved.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Except once she had her money, she left you. Went back to her partying lifestyle.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: She used you. But there wasn’t anything you could do about it. At least, not without admitting to the murder.

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: You can’t prove that. His death wasn’t even ruled a homicide.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: No, but Barbra Landau’s was.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Uniforms found this 9 millimeter in a dumpster behind your offices. Ballistics match. This is the same gun that was used to kill Barbra Landau and it’s got your fingerprints all over it.

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: Last month her credit card bills were so high, I thought she was slipping back into her old ways. I said to her, ‘we didn’t risk everything to get this money so you could let it ruin your life’. And she looked at me and I could tell she had no idea what I was talking about. In that moment I knew she wasn’t my Odette.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And that’s how she got on to you.

utterance.speaker: LYNCHBERG
utterance.content: So this Barbra told me that if I kept her secret she would keep mine. She thought we were even. She thought that she could just take the place of Odette. What – what was I supposed to do? Just let some dirty stripper live in her house and wear her clothes and – and blackmail me? Odette deserved better.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I was just thinking about how we rely on dreams to keep us going in life and how sad it is when they become the things that tear us down.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah well, that might be the case for Barbra Landau, but not for everyone with dreams that didn’t come true. I mean, take Lanie for instance. She wanted to be a dancer. She became a doctor. That’s not so bad, is it?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hum. What about you? I mean, we know you became a cop because your mother was murdered, but there had to be something before that. What did little Kate Beckett want to be when she grew up?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: At Stanford I was pre-law.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So your dream was to argue a case in front of the Supreme Court.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mmhmm. Yep. I was on my way to becoming the first female Chief Justice.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mmhmm.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Not bad.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Argh! It won’t – you know what? Ooh! I’m late for my stripper date.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Whoa whoa whoa … no, no. I – I cannot go home again without that ring on my finger tonight. My couch has a loose spring, my back –

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hey, did you try soap?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Yeah, it was like the first thing we did.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Cooking spray?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: I didn’t think about cooking spray.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Here.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: It’s like silk.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: That might work.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Oh yeah.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: I think it’s coming.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: At least it’s off my finger.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oona, thank you so much for stopping by.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Thank you. Martha. And I’ll be sure to find a few inches of column space to mention your little school.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oh, good. Thank you. I really appreciate that, dear.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oh Richard, you’re just in time to say goodbye to Oona.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, how nice to see you again.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: It’s lovely see you as well. And I … look forward to hearing from you.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hearing from –

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Well, I know you’re in a hurry, dear. And um, I’ll call you. We will have lunch.

utterance.speaker: OONA
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Yes. Bye-bye.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Aaaahhh! All's well that ends well.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Mother, why would Oona Marconi be looking forward to hearing from me?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Well, you did say if there was any way you could help …

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That you should let me know. Exactly what did you promise her without asking me first?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: That you would read her novel.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, Mother.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: And critique it and give it to your publisher. It is the inspiring story of a young woman’s journey from a department store clerk to world renowned Broadway star.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Chick lit? Mother, this is really not my -

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Oh, and darling? When you give her your thoughts, do be kind. Because it’s always been her dream to be a novelist.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Be kind. For you, Mother … I can be kind.
